QuestionText: Which algorithm is commonly used to reduce dimensionality in data science by projecting data onto a lower-dimensional subspace?
What is a key characteristic of the Random Forest algorithm in machine learning?
OptionA: It is based on a single decision tree.
OptionB: It combines multiple decision trees for better accuracy.
OptionC: It projects data into a higher-dimensional space.
OptionD: It clusters data based on similarity metrics.

QuestionText: In which situation would you use ROC-AUC as a metric in data science?
OptionB: When evaluating classification models with imbalanced classes.
OptionC: When measuring variance in regression models.

QuestionText: What is overfitting in the context of machine learning models?
OptionA: When the model underestimates relationships in the dataset.
OptionB: When the model performs well on new, unseen data.
OptionC: When the model performs well on training data but poorly on test data.
OptionD: When the model uses hyperparameters for optimization.

QuestionText: Which of the following is NOT a type of supervised learning algorithm?
What is the primary purpose of a confusion matrix in classification problems?
OptionA: To evaluate the correlation between variables.
OptionB: To summarize the performance of a classification model.
OptionD: To visualize the distribution of a dataset.

QuestionText: Which method is used to handle missing data in a dataset?
OptionC: Transforming the data using log transformation.

QuestionText: What is the primary role of gradient descent in machine learning?
OptionA: To find the optimal hyperparameters for a model.
OptionB: To minimize the cost function by iteratively adjusting model parameters.
OptionC: To split datasets into training and testing sets.
OptionD: To improve computational efficiency through parallel processing.

QuestionText: Which of these Python libraries is most commonly used for data manipulation and analysis?
What is the curse of dimensionality in the context of data science?
OptionA: When a model scales poorly with smaller datasets.
OptionB: When the number of dimensions causes sparse data and makes modeling difficult.
OptionC: When having more features always leads to better predictions.
OptionD: When datasets have highly correlated variables.
